editionStmt.funder: Conversion of the printed catalogue to TEI funded by the Thompson Family Charitable Trust

msDesc.head: Miscellany: medicine and astronomy; Bestiary; Guillaume de Conches, Dragmaticon; Cato and glossaries in Anglo-Norman

supportDesc.support: Comprising six separate MSS, all on vellum (all FSOS/FHHF), of which the portions designated ‘Manuscript 2’ and ‘Manuscript 4’ below (fols. 9–144, 156–357) seem to be a core around which different parts have accreted.
supportDesc.extent: Fols. iii + 415 (numbered fols. iv–vii, 1–411) + v (numbered fols. viii–xii). 190 140
supportDesc.foliation: A fifteenth-century foliation for fols. 1–281 (the current folio 277), to match the contents table on fol. iii (this foliation omits 55, has 78 for 77 as well as 78; later has 229, 22, 230, 233, and includes numeration for a lost bifolium after fol. 172).

decoDesc.decoNote: The main scribe portions only: headings within texts in red; colophons and incipits written in text ink in a larger, more decorative anglicana.
Two- and 3-line alternate red and blue lombards on flourishing of the other colour at textual divisions.
Some texts divided by red- or ochre-slashed capitals (the latter only in item 21) or red paraphs.
Numerous coloured diagrams in texts 1, 5, and 21.
Full illuminations include the zodiac man (fol. 142).

The Bestiary is illustrated to fol. 194v, with about ninety small pictures, typically set into the text area. The largest illumination occupies three-quarters of fol. 169v, with three cartoons to illustrate Canis. Other largish illuminations include another for Canis (fol. 170), Adam naming the animals (fol. 171v), and a dragon waiting under the tree ‘perindeus’ for doves to fall off into its mouth (fol. 185).

The MS appears at Lucy Freeman Sandler, Gothic Manuscripts, 1285–1385, 2 vols. (London, 1986) as, no. 39 (2:45). See AT, no. 264 (27), identifying the hand as London work (Calendar of St Peter’s, Westminster) and plate xvi (fols. 142, 169v, 185). Illustrations from the MS, especially the zodiac man, have often been reproduced: see Sandler, plates 86 (fol. 165, the goat from the Bestiary) and 87 (fol. 142, the zodiac man); Marcel Destombes, Mappemondes A.D. 1200–1500, nos. 27.11 (fol. 37v, 61) and 41.10 (fols. 324v, 333v, 107); Sandler, The Psalter of Robert de Lisle in the British Library (Oxford, 1983), 17, 102 nn. 24–5, fig. 9 (fol. 142); Fritz Saxl and Hans Meier, ed. Harry Bober, Catalogue of Astrological and Mythological Illuminated Manuscripts of the Latin Middle Ages 3, 2 vols. (London, 1953), 1:413 and 2:figure 240 (plate xcii, fol. 142).

binding.p: A modern replacement. Sewn on five thongs. At the front, a marbled paper leaf, and six vellum flyleaves, four part of the actual volume (fols. iii–vv are waste, bounded and ruled, fol. v pricked); at the rear, four medieval vellum flyleaves and another marbled leaf (viii–xii).

history.provenance: ‘Isti libri continentur in hoc volumine beati petri Westm’ (fol. iii; anglicana, s. xv2/4) (Ker MLGB 197).

‘Symondus Hampton Iste liber est Ecclesie Beati P’ [around this in ink ‘Symond’, ‘Philippus Symond’ ‘Iohanna Symond’ ‘Iohannes Symond’] (fol. xv, s. xv in red around a 4-line musical stave); the same names appear again on fol. xi, with the addition of ‘Ricardus Sowtbroke’.
A note on the zodiac, which includes names: ‘Iohannes Iohannes hunger ’ (fol. 38v, lower margin, erased, s. xvi1/2).
Various pen-trials (fols. iv [s. xvi ex.], viii, and fol. xv [both s. xvi in.]).
'George Whalley owth this boke’ (fol. vv, s. xvi), below it two verses in Spanish: ‘No es mego de riere Alenez cara (s. xvi ex. italic).

source.bibl: Ralph Hanna, A descriptive catalogue of the western medieval manuscripts of St. John's College, Oxford (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2002)

availability.p: For enquiries relating to this manuscript please contact St John's College Library.

Bursill-Hall, G. L., A Census of Medieval Grammatical Manuscripts, Grammatica speculativa 4 (Stuttgart, 1980).
Dekkers, Eligius, and Aemilius Gaar, Clavis patrum latinorum, 3rd edn. (Turnhout, 1995).
Destombes, Marcel, Mappemondes A.D. 1200–1500.
Ewert, A., ‘A Fourteenth-Century Latin-French Nominale’, Medium Ævum 3 (14), 13–18.
Fontaine, J. (ed.), Traité de la nature (Bordeaux, 1960), 167–327.
Fowler-Magerl, Linda, Ordo iudiciorum vel ordo iudicarius, Ius commune 19 (Frankfurt a. M., 1984), 144–5.

Hunt, Tony, Teaching and Learning Latin in Thirteenth-Century England (Cambridge: Brewer, 1991).

James, M. R., The Bestiary, Roxburghe Club (Oxford, 1928).

Ker, N. R., Medieval Libraries of Great Britain: A List of Surviving Books. Royal Historical Society Guides and Handbooks. 2nd edn. (London, 1964), extended by Andrew G. Watson, MLGB: Supplement to the Second Edition. RHS Guides and Handbooks 15 (1987).

Meyer, Paul (ed.), ‘Notice sur les Corrogationes Promethei d’Alexandre Neckam’, Notices et extraits des Manuscrits de Ia Bibliothèque Nationale 35, ii (1896), 641–82.
Möller, Reinhold (ed.), Hiltgart von Hürnheim Mittelhochdeutsche Prosaübersetzung des ‘Secreta Secretorum’ (Berlin, 1963).
Perry, Ben E.Secundus the Silent Philosopher (Ithaca, NY, 1964).
Ronca, Italo, William of Conches, Dragmaticon Philosophiae, Corpus Christianorum Continuatio Mediaevalis 152 (Turnhout: Brepols, 1997).
Sandler, Lucy Freeman, Gothic Manuscripts, 1285–1385, 2 vols. (London, 1986).
Sandler, Lucy Freeman , The Psalter of Robert de Lisle in the British Library (Oxford, 1983).
Saxl, Fritz, and Hans Meier, ed. Harry Bober, Catalogue of Astrological and Mythological Illuminated Manuscripts of the Latin Middle Ages 3, 2 vols. (London, 1953).
Schmitt, C. B. and D. Knox (eds), Pseudo-Aristoteles Latinus: A Guide to Latin Works Falseley Attributed to Aristotle before 1500 (London, 1985).
Sharpe, Richard, A Handlist of the Latin Writers of Great Britain and Ireland before 1540. Publications of the Journal of Medieval Latin 1 (Turnhout, 1997).
Thorndike, Lynn, ‘De Complexionibus’, Isis 49 (1958), 398–408.
Thorndike, Lynn, ‘Notes on Some Less Familiar British Astronomical and Astrological Manuscripts’, Journal of the Warburg and Courtauld Institutes 22 (1959) 157–71.
Thorndike, Lynn (ed.), The Sphere of Sacrobosco and Its Commentators (Chicago, 1949), 76–117.
Thorndike, Lynn, and Pearl Kibre, A Catalogue of Incipits of Medieval Scientific Writings in Latin, 2nd edn. (Cambridge, Mass., 1963).
Walther, Hans, Initia carminum ac versuum Medii Aevi posterioris Latinorum, 2nd edn (Göttingen, 1969).
Walther, Hans, Proverbia sententiaeque latinitatis medii aevi: Lateinische Sprichwörter, 5 vols. (Göttingen, 1963-7)

msItem.note: a cropped vellum leaf from a noted Breviary in double columns (s. xv), mounted with the page foot at leading edge, with a College bookplate on the verso.
‘Isti libri continentur in hoc volumine beati petri Westm’, a table of contents, in anglicana, s. xv2/4.
ruled in red for music.

note.p: ‘Ihesus passion be myn helpe’, with four or five sets of verses (only one in Walther) in the same hand, mixed anglicana/secretary, s. xv med.
(i) ‘Secundum ingeniolum meum carismate aspirante compendiose declarabo etc.’
(ii) ‘Cum pare pugnare dubium forciori dampnum | Cum puero pudor est sic pax super omnia prodest’.
(iii) ‘Silencium est frenum claustralium et ideo claustralis sine silencio est quasi equus sine freno’.
(iv–v) ‘Quondam scire nichil vicium fuit est modo risus | Est modo nil vicium preter habere nichil || Antiquo more sapiencia prefuit auro | Presenti vere melius nil indico stauro [l. stanno?]’.

msItem.note: ‘Si culpare velis culpabilis esse cauebis | Dogma tuum sordet cum te tua culpa remordet’ (Walter, Sprichwörter, no. 28372, varied), in a hand resembling that which copied the contents table; and recopied below, s. xv ex.

msItem.locus: Fol. xv below the signature (see Provenance below):
msItem.note: ‘Sancti spiritus assit nobis gracia | Que corda nostra sibi faceat habitacula | Expulsi inde cunctis spiritalibus’ (s. xv ex.).
Robertum sarum robur decus ecclesiarum | Te matri carum vis—Ille suis donis sedem det nunc vnionis’, below the preceding, in six couplets, s. xv3/4, not in Walther.

‘Hec est tabula terminorum que est prima de compoto comuni’, with a table of moon signs (fol. 2v) and calendar (fols. 3–8v). Among feasts in red are ‘cathedra sancti Petri’ (21 February), Guthlac, Elphegus, Botulph, Philbert abbot, and Edmund Rich.

supportDesc.collation: 18 24 (not clearly bifolia). No catchwords or signatures.

msItem.rubric: Incipit epistola Beati YSIDORIJ IPALENSIS vrbis Episcopi ad Sisebucum de Naturis rerum
msItem.incipit: Domino et filio Sisebuto ysodorus salutem Dum te prestantem ingenio facundiaque ac vario flore litterarum
msItem.rubric: [fol. 10, the text] Incipit liber beati YSIDRI IPALENSIS vrbis Episcopi ad sesebucum de naturis rerum De diebus
msItem.incipit: Dies est solis orientis presencia vsque ad occasum perueniat
msItem.explicit: mensuram geometrici clxxx. milium stadiorum estimauerunt Cuius terre exposicionem in medio occeano subiecta declarat formula
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit liber beati YSODORII SPALENSIS episcopi de naturis rerum
msItem.author: ISIDORE OF SEVILLE
msItem.title: De natura rereum
msItem.note: CPL 1188, ed. J. Fontaine, Traité de la nature (Bordeaux, 1960), 167–327. A contents table on fols. 9v–10 with a second one-sentence prologue. In this portion of the MS, persistent instructions to the rubricator in crayon at the page foot.

msItem.rubric: Summus itaque planetarum
msItem.incipit: saturnus dicitur in peragrinacione zodiaci fere xxx. annos consumens
msItem.explicit: Aquarum Calidos et humidos Cancrum Scorpionem et Pisces frigidos et humidos
msItem.note: TK 1539, cited from Erfurt, Wissensch. Bibliothek der Stadt, MS Amplonianum F.346, fols. 18v–19.

msItem.rubric: Incipit tractatus tractus ARISTOTILIS de iiijor. humoribus
msItem.incipit: Elementum est simpla et Minima pars corporis compositi Elementa igitur quatuor sunt
msItem.explicit: Et mulieres si commederint ab omni partu euacuantur testante Ieronimo et medicis pluribus Explicit
msItem.author: PS. -ARISTOTLE
msItem.title: 'de quatuor humoribus'
msItem.note: (TK 496, PAL no. 79 (54)); discussed and partially translated from our MS by Lynn Thorndike, ‘De Complexionibus’, Isis 49 (1958), 398–408 at 406–8.

msItem.rubric: Forma Chilindri hec est
msItem.incipit: Describe quartam partem circuli et diuide eam in congrue partes
msItem.explicit: sint ab origine mundi vsque ad eundem terminum vjM6CI. annum dj.
msItem.note: On the cylinder, with further notes on various kinds of measurement (TK 567).

msItem.rubric: Incipit algorismus
msItem.incipit: Omnia que sunt a primeua rerum origine processerunt racione numerorum formata sunt
msItem.explicit: qui modus comparandi est idem cum predicto Et hec de radicum extraccione sufficiant
msItem.author: JOHANNES DE SACRO BOSCO
msItem.title: Algorismus
msItem.note: (TK 1295), ed. Maximilian Curtze, Petri Philomeni de Dacia in Algorismum vulgarem Johannis de Sacrobosco Commentarius (Copenhagen, 1897), 1–19.

msItem.rubric: Incipit tractatus de Spera
msItem.incipit: Tractatum de spera quatuor capitulis distinguimus dicentes primo quid sit spera [fol. 54] Spera ab euclide sic describitur spera est transitus circumferencie dimidii
msItem.explicit: in eadem passione dixisse aut deus nature patitur aut Machina mundi dissoluetur
msItem.author: JOHANNES DE SACRO BOSCO
msItem.title: Tractatus de Sphera
msItem.note: (Sharpe, no. 865 [306]), ed. Lynn Thorndike, The Sphere of Sacrobosco and Its Commentators (Chicago, 1949), 76–117. Three diagrams on fol. 71v.

msItem.rubric: Incipit compotus
msItem.incipit: Compotus est sciencia considerans tempora ex solis et lune motibus
msItem.explicit: ire iubes stabilisque manens das cuncta moueri Tu stabilire velis et cetera
msItem.author: JOHANNES DE SACRO BOSCO
msItem.title: Compotus
msItem.note: ed. Libellus de anni ratione seu ut uocatur uulgo Computus Ecclesiasticus (Paris, 1550), fols. 5–54. Fol. 103v has a ‘Cribrum BOETIJ de Multiplicacione numerorum’.

msItem.rubric: Incipit prologus Magistri ALEXANDRI NEQUAM
msItem.incipit: Ferrum situ rubiginem trahit Et vitis non putata in labruscam Siluescit [the text]
msItem.rubric: Vtrum grammatica sit ars
msItem.incipit: Excellentissimo philosopho platoni visum est gramaticam non esse censendam nomine artis
msItem.explicit: lineam non sequitur Similiter et senex delirus horus deliret acumen
msItem.author: ALEXANDER NEQUAM
msItem.title: Corrogationes Promethei
msItem.note: part 1 only (Sharpe, no. 102 [51–3]); only excerpts have been printed, ed. Paul Meyer, ‘Notice sur les Corrogationes Promethei d’Alexandre Neckam’, Notices et extraits des Manuscrits de Ia Bibliothèque Nationale 35, ii (1896), 641–82.

msItem.rubric: Incipiunt cautele super Algorismum
msItem.incipit: | [fol. 138v] Duabus rebus existentibus in duabus manibus ut sciatur que res in qua manu sit
msItem.explicit: erit prima pars sexta pars tocius secunda vero media pars tertia autem tripulum

msItem.rubric: Istud sequens capitulum in cognicionem mansionis lune est editum
msItem.incipit: Artem ad cognoscendum in quo signo et in quo gradu signi sit luna sit luna cotidie hanc attende
msItem.explicit: ad pedes et ad corum extremitates et eorum neruos et ad eorum infirmitates vt est dolor et podagra etc
msItem.note: TK 145. The material on the moon is followed by a second chapter, including verses on the planets, a table of lunar houses, and materials on the zodiacal signs; fol. 142 has a full-page illustration of a zodiacal man, with two distichs below the text, inc. ‘Ista sex signa que sunt a principio arietis ’ Lynn Thorndike discusses items 11–14 in ‘Notes on Some Less Familiar British Astronomical and Astrological Manuscripts’, Journal of the Warburg and Courtauld Institutes 22 (1959) 157–71 at 160–1.

msItem.incipit: Moderitus dicit Luna duabus diebus et vj. horas ac bisse vnius hore per singula signa labitur
msItem.explicit: incisio non debet fieri in membro aliquo luna existente in signo membrum illud significante
msItem.note: Further zodiacal notes (TK 877). In this and the two following texts, a variety of added notes in the lower margin.

msItem.rubric: Tractatus accidencium et effectuum alphel Secundum lunares mansiones in vnoque et xij. Signis
msItem.incipit: Luna existente in Ariete sanguinem minuere et balneis vti bonum est
msItem.explicit: Leo est signum Masculinum Uirgo est signum feminitiuum Libra est signum Masculinum
msItem.title: A lunary

msItem.incipit: Quando uolueris ut qui sunt in palacio videantur nigri tunc accipe ex spuma maris
msItem.explicit: faculus plenus sale tosto parti dolenti superponatur vel coquatur clauo de Cupro
msItem.note: Recipes, more than half in French (TK 1172).

supportDesc.collation: 3–912 1014 1112 1214 1312. Catchwords; all leaves in the first half of each quire signed, with a letter or a roman (rarely arabic) numeral. Quire 10 may have been constructed as a long quire ending a booklet, but the potential fascicle boundary was then abandoned to continue the book.

layoutDesc.layout: In long lines, 22 lines to the page. Prickings rare; apparently bounded and ruled in lead but either faded or erased.

handDesc.handNote: Written in anglicana, s. xiv in.; the hand is reminiscent of that in the Shropshire miscellany BL, MS Harley 2253. Punctuation by point only.

msItem.rubric: Incipit explanacio breuis de dictis Esdre prophete gallice probatis
msItem.incipit: Ces sunt les diz Esdras le prophete ky en ierusalem prophezat Si le iour de lan remis auient par dymaigne
msItem.explicit: Si il lust le secund ior donc ert or et argent legier a conquere
msItem.title: Prognostics according to the day on which the new year falls, in Anglo-Norman.

msItem.rubric: Subiungentur admiracionis causa quedam antiquorum opiniones que etiam a nullis modernorum quam plurimum reprobantur
msItem.incipit: Lvna prima omnibus rebus faciendis vtilis est Puer natus illustris et vitalis erit
msItem.explicit: affabilis et honorificus Forma vero qui nascetur utilis erit
msItem.note: TK 837, analogues noted in Thorndike, 1:680 n. 1. The text also appears in Cambridge, Trinity College MS O.7.23, fol. 68v. Followed (fol. 149rv) by a variety of medical notes and verses.

msItem.incipit: Iudicium est actus trium personarum videlicet Iudicis actoris et rei et testis iiijo. notator
msItem.explicit: habere litteras testimonias de sua conuersacione in suo recessu de dicto hospicio
msItem.note: A unique guide for procedure, presumably in Westminster courts and postdating the canonical collection Extra (1234), discussed by Linda Fowler-Magerl, Ordo iudiciorum vel ordo iudicarius, Ius commune 19 (Frankfurt a. M., 1984), 144–5.

supportDesc.collation: 146+6 (+2, +3 [a bifolium], +4, +5 [another bifolium], +10, +11 [a third bifolium], –12 [probably blank]) (see Additional Commentary below). No catchwords; the first five leaves signed with roman numerals in red. This quire/MS appears to have been subject to processes of extension in production. Originally the scribe seems to have contemplated only the first two astronomical texts and economically supplied a series of bifolia to compete, and subsequently extend, this work.

layoutDesc.layout: In long lines, 29 lines to the page. No prickings; bounded and ruled in brown crayon and lead.

handDesc.handNote: In gothic textura rotunda with anglicana letter forms, s. xiii2. Punctuation by point only.

msItem.rubric: Incipit primus liber de naturis bestiarum
msItem.incipit: Leo fortissimus Bestiarum ad nullius pauebit occursum Bestiarum vocabulum proprie conuenit Leonibus
msItem.explicit: [fol. 216v] est condere corpora nam humare obruere dicimus hoc est humum in itinere itere
msItem.incipit: Explicit Svnt lapides igniferi in quodam monte
msItem.explicit: ab adam vsque in folios inobediencie debachatur
msItem.title: The Bestiary
msItem.note: a text of the ‘second family’; see M. R. James, The Bestiary, Roxburghe Club (Oxford, 1928). There is missing text between fols. 172 and 173.

msItem.rubric: Hic incipiunt secreta secretorum ARISTOTILIS
msItem.incipit: | [fol. 217v] Domino sui excellentissimo in cultu Religionis cristiane srenuissimo Gwidoni vere de valencia cuitatis Tripolis glorioso ponticifi PHILIPPUS suorum Minimus clericorum Quanto luna ceteris stellis est lucidior et solis radius lucidate Lune fulgencior [fol. 218v] Deus omnipotens custodiat regem nostrum gloriam credencium et confirmet regnum suum [fol 219v] Iohannes qui transtulit istum librum filius Patricii Linguarum interpretate peritissimus Fili karissime et gloriosissime imperator iustissime confirmet te deus in via cognoscendi
msItem.explicit: magnificum Alexandrum qui dominates fuit toto orbi ductus Monarcha in septemtrione
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit liber ARISTOTILIS de secretis secretorum
msItem.author: PS.-ARISTOTLE
msItem.title: Secreta secretorum
msItem.note: PHILIP OF TRIPOLI’s translation (PAL, no. 81 [54–75], our copy noted at 69); ed. Reinhold Möller, Hiltgart von Hürnheim Mittelhochdeutsche Prosaübersetzung des ‘Secreta Secretorum’ (Berlin, 1963), 1–2, 14–164.

msItem.rubric: Et incipit explanatio breuis et compendiosi numerandi
msItem.incipit: Omnis numerus aut est digitus aut articulus aut compositus dignitus
msItem.explicit: Septimus loco M Millesies et sie deinceps
msItem.note: TK 999. Followed by a table of roman numerals and their arabic equivalents.

supportDesc.collation: 1512 1612 (–6, –7) 17–2312. Catchwords; all leaves in the first half of quires 21–23 signed with roman numerals in red (perhaps cut away elsewhere).

layoutDesc.layout: In long lines, 27 lines to the page. No apparent pricking, bounds, or rules.

handDesc.handNote: Written by the scribe of Manuscript 2, here the hand appearing more developed, perhaps of s. xiv2/4. Punctuation by point only.

msItem.incipit: Queris venerande Dux Normanmorum et Comes Andegauensium cur Magistris nostri temporis minus creditor quam antiquis
msItem.explicit: memoria et delirant homines Extincto vero naturali calore desinit homo viuere
msItem.note: ‘Questiones ad philosophum’ (table), in fact GUILLAUME DE CONCHES, Dragmaticon philosophiae, ed. I. Ronca, CCCM 152 (1997), 3–270, with our copy collated as O1 (described pp. LI–LII).

msItem.rubric: De SECUNDO Philosopho
msItem.incipit: Secundus philosophos philisophatus est omni tempore silencium conseruans et pictagoricam ducens vitam
msItem.explicit: Mundus est incessabilis circuitus Spectabilis suppellex per se genitum torreuma
msItem.title: De Secundo Philosopho
msItem.note: Roughly corresponds to WILLIAM OF GAP’s translation from Greek, to section 8 only, ed. Ben E. Perry, Secundus the Silent Philosopher (Ithaca, NY, 1964), 92–4.

msItem.rubric: Incipit Explanacio quorundam verborum que sub una significacione tam neutra Sunt quam deponencia
msItem.incipit: Sunt quedam verba sub vna significacione tam neutra quam deponencia vt latino neutrum
msItem.explicit: vnde virgilius in georgicis Aut tenuis fetus uicie tristesque lupini
msItem.note: Unidentified; not in Bursill-Hall.

supportDesc.collation: 24–3112. Catchwords (a few cut away); all leaves in the first half of quires 27 and 29 signed with roman numerals.

layoutDesc.layout: In long lines, 22–5 lines to the page. No prickings, bounded and ruled in lead.

handDesc.handNote: In the same anglicana of s. xiv in. or xiv2/4 as the preceding (and MS 2). Punctuation by point only.

msItem.rubric: Incipit Nodus In cirpo
msItem.incipit: Introducendis in artem grammaticam primo uidendum est quid sit grammatica et vnde dicatur [the poem begins] Ad presens edam pueris puerilia quedam [interlinear gloss] id est in presenti opere componam vel ostendam artem [explanatory gloss] Edo es quando inequaliter declinatur significat commedo et facit preteritum edi
msItem.explicit: [fol. 387, the poem ends] Que pretermittentur geminis acuenda uidentur [the gloss ends] secundum predictas regulas accentuum Et hec de accentibus ad presens dicta sufficiant
msItem.author: JOHN OF BEAUVAIS
msItem.title: 'Liber pauperum'
msItem.note: (Walther, no. 421), another copy in BL, MS Royal 15 B.iv; see Stephen A. Hurlbut, ‘A Forerunner of Alexander de Villa-Dei’, Speculum 8 (1933), 258–63 at 263 n. 1, and our copy noted by Bursill-Hall, 184. With an interlinear and a fully explanatory gloss. Scribal prayer in upper margin of first page; four additional grammatical notes by the scribe ‘Robertus’ follow the explicit.

msItem.incipit: Pater noster qui es in celis sanctificetur nomen tuum et In hac locucione ponitur hoc relatiuum qui ergo refert ad aliquod antecedens queratur ad quod
msItem.explicit: per inplicationem refert hoc pronomen ille et conuenit sue relacioni cum ipsam
msItem.note: A grammatical commentary on the Paternoster (Bloomfield, no. 8464).

msItem.incipit: Ki uolt sauoir la faitement que catun a sun fiz aprent | Si en latin nel set entendre [fol. 391v, the actual translation begins] Si par pense pure cum dist la scripture | Seit hum deu cultiuer [the Latin] Si deus est animus nobis ut carmina dicunt
msItem.explicit: [the Latin] Hoc breuitas sensus fecit coniungere binos Kest en raisun un ueirs deus sulement | Kil translata entent tut al trefi | Sanz dyes dunt ihesu ait merci Amen
msItem.author: ELIAS OF WINCHESTER
msItem.title: The Distichs of Cato
msItem.note: in Anglo-Norman verse, with the Latin original written in the gloss hand, both marginally and in alternate lines, unpublished; see M. Dominica Legge, Anglo-Norman Literature and Its Background (Oxford, 1963), 182. A different scribe writing in the same page frame as the preceding MS. Fol. 397v is blank.

layoutDesc.layout: In long lines, 42 lines to the page. No prickings; bounded and ruled in brown ink.

handDesc.handNote: Written in gothic textura prescissa (text) and quadrata (gloss), different sizes for text and gloss, on the whole above top line, s. xiii1. Punctuation by medial point and punctus elevatus.

msItem.incipit: [the text] Qui ille scilicet bene wlt disponere ordoner familie a sa meine sue et rebus suis prouiderat purueit sibi in vtensilibus [the marginal gloss] Sepe damus flammis cepum sicesc’e cepas Visis sepi per sepem [the gloss tails off, extensively filled only to fol. 400]
msItem.explicit: alium in cirografis sub breuitate et compendiose per apices par titles scribi debet Explicit Liber
msItem.note: The Latin is ALEXANDER NEQUAM, ‘De nominibus utensilium’ (Sharpe, no. 102 [51–3]), ed. Tony Hunt, Teaching and Learning Latin in Thirteenth-Century England (Cambridge: Brewer, 1991), 1:177–189/23.

msItem.incipit: Quis nescit quam sit nobile uulgus | In o ceram exuit sonus eo
msItem.explicit: facit cito per se | Nummus habet ceruos quibus auget fetus aceruos

note.p: Latin verses (Walther, no. 16086, with half a dozen English copies), followed by eight verses over erasure and (from fol. 408) grammatical notes and verses in a variety of hands, s. xiii ex. These include (fol. 408va) the ‘versus de synonymis’ cited by Bursill-Hall, inc. ‘Balnea cornici quid prosunt quid meretrici’ (Walther, no. 2052).

msItem.rubric: Responsio SECUNDI philosophi ad arrianum imperatorem
msItem.incipit: Dixit secundus philosophus Mundus est constitucio celi et terre et omnium que in eis
msItem.explicit: Equalitas animorum Quid fides est Ignote rei miranda certitudo
msItem.note: As item 22 above, and following on from its explicit, ed. Perry, 94–100. Followed by a pair of verses ‘Pacto lex cedit pacto lex omnis obedit | Quolibet in facto lex est obnoxia pacto’ (not in Walther).

msItem.incipit: Hec anima alme hic uel hoc homo homme hic uel hoc nemo hoc corpus cors hoc capud chef
msItem.explicit: arundo suggit arudo arundo crescit Mundo hic circulus curua
msItem.note: A Latin-Anglo-Norman nominale, partly ed. A. Ewert, ‘A Fourteenth-Century Latin-French Nominale’, Medium Ævum 3 (14), 13–18; see further Tony Hunt, ‘The Anglo-Norman Vocabularies in MS Oxford, Bodleian Library Douce 88’, Medium Ævum 49 (1980), 5–25, where our copy is collated; and cf. Hunt, Learning Latin, 401.

layoutDesc.layout: For text 27, writing area a central text column 162 55 on alternate lines to allow glosses, between two gloss columns mm wide along the gutter and 40 mm wide along the leading edge. In long lines, 24 lines of text, 59 lines of gloss to the page. No prickings, bounded and ruled in brown crayon.
The remainder, to fol. 410, in rough double columns and a variety of different hands adding grammatical notes of various types. The succeeding nominale is in four columns.

handDesc.handNote: Written in gothic textura semiquadrata, s. xiii2. Punctuation by point, medial point, and occasional punctus elevatus.
